Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: The genetics underlying adaptive diversification of mimicry patterns in bumble bees
Award.AbstractNarration:
New advances in genomics allow for the discovery of the genes responsible for specific traits of organisms and for complex patterns of trait variation that have evolved in species across their geographic range. To better understand the evolutionary mechanisms that determine trait variation and that promote rapid adaptation to environmental change, studies are needed that can link traits to the genes that encode them, especially in species that show extraordinary trait variation. Bumble bees (Bombus) are especially suited for such research: the 250 species worldwide have evolved to exhibit >600 color patterns, in which similar color patterns evolve in different species when they live in the same geographical location. This project will explore how these different color patterns form in Bumble Bee species across North America by identifying the pigments that are responsible for color patterns and then identifying the genes responsible for those pigments and the observed geographic patterns of color variation. This research will provide general insights into how color variation arises in nature, and will also help to address a long standing question in evolutionary biology regarding the repeatability of evolution. Are the same genes in different species responsible for the same color patterns or are different genes able to produce the same color patterns? This research will directly address this question and in answering it help us understand whether evolution is truly repeatable or whether it just looks repeatable and that there are many evolutionary paths to get to the same outcome.

This CAREER project builds foundational knowledge on the genetic and evolutionary processes enabling the mimetic radiation of bumble bees. The project will address the mimetic process by characterizing the geographic distribution of color patterns in North America bumble bees and how they are impacted by climate. It will reveal how these bees are pigmented and the factors that influence their coloration, providing a foundation for further genetic work. Pigment discovery will extend to a diversity of insects through undergraduate research and classroom modules on insect pigment chemistry. As a primary aim, gene mapping and gene expression approaches will be used to identify genes driving red/black and yellow/black bumble bee color variation. Black and yellow pattern morphs of the subgenus Bombus will demonstrate how adaptive gene variants are transferred across species, populations, and sexes. The discovery of the genes behind black and red mimetic convergence in western U.S. bumble bees will inform on the genetic complexity underlying bumble bee mimicry. Identifying these genes will enable a broader comparative approach to examine how adaptive genes have been targeted and transferred across this replicate-rich radiation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project gained insights into how genotypic change generates adaptive phenotypic diversity by deciphering the genetic basis of repeated evolution of mimetic color patterns in bumble bees. This included comparing the genes driving parallel evolution of red vs. black mid-abdominal mimetic color variation across multiple bumble bee species in the Western United States. As foundational data, the project characterized morphological shifts in bumble bee pupal development, a valuable reference for bee research, and revealed the red/black variation in these bees to involve melanins. In bumble bee Bombus melanopygus, genomic and gene expression assays across development revealed this color variation to be driven by mutations switching the location of Hox gene AbdominalB (AbdB) - a major developmental gene that regulates the fate of posterior body segments - to more anterior segments. While such a spatial shift normally would result in major changes in segmental identity, the modification of this gene late in development enabled employment of a major developmental gene with little non-targeted consequences. Transcriptome analyses revealed the gene network from AbdB to a suite of interacting genes in the melanin pathway that impart the melanic change, connecting the genetic mutation to final phenotype in this non-model system. Analyzing other mimetic species revealed that these same mutations do not drive parallel color changes even in close relatives, supporting the propensity for novel mutations to generate adaptive change. However, another species with the same red and black mimicry forms was found to use a different mutation in the same regulatory region of the AbdB gene, supporting how certain genomic locations are evolutionary hotspots that enable diversity. In addition to contributions in evolutionary genetics, this study enhanced understanding of evolutionary processes by providing a detailed quantification of mimetic color distribution in bumble bees across the United States. This revealed that mimicry patterns transition from west to east with low fidelity zones of imperfect mimicry between zones of high fidelity mimics. The genetic data from this study enabled resolution of speciation processes in several bumble bees including the discovery of a new species concealed by mimicry. This project also led to the development of a new analytical tool for genomic analysis, and a machine learning tool for quantifying similarity in appearance across organisms that has applications such as assessing mimicry and image-based developmental staging. This project provides a genetic foundation for future research across the vast diversity of this lineage, and shows the potential for deciphering genetic mechanisms underlying natural diversity in non-model systems of evolutionary and ecological importance. Towards these insights, this award has resulted in at least 15 publications and 32 scientific presentations. It enhanced integrative cross-disciplinary thinking in undergraduate education through development and teaching of a hands-on laboratory module in an undergraduate analytical chemistry course involving novel discovery of unknown pigments in insects. Insights and principles from this research were communicated to the public through numerous blog and news articles, as well as through several outreach activities to the broader community (Great Insect Fair, mimicry displays at the Frost Entomological Museum), elementary school children (Nature Explorers Summer Camp), and high school students (PA School of Excellence in Ag Sciences; Upward Bound Summer Program). This project advanced the training of the next generation of scientists, supporting 2 postdoctoral researchers, 3 graduate students, 2 graduate rotation students, 7 undergraduate researchers, and the development of the research program of the PI.
